input:

45:40 Caption: Santi Cazorla (Arsenal) sends in a cross from a free kick from just outside the box, trying to find one of his teammates deep inside the penalty area. The goalkeeper displays great anticipation and collects the ball.
46:05 Caption: The referee blows his whistle to end the first half and the players are now heading to their respective dressing rooms.
46:59 Caption: The performance of both teams has been far from perfect so far and is unlikely to have satisfied the fans. Both teams are unsuccessfully trying to control the game and it's pretty even so far. Long balls and crosses are the strongest weapons of the home team. The away team tries to find the weakness in the opposition's defence using mainly rapid counter-attacks.

45:32 Caption: The ball rebounds and arrives at the feet of Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain (Arsenal) just outside the box. He doesn't think twice and fires a brilliant shot inside the right post. His attempt was beyond the reach of Danijel Subasic, so the score changes to 0:2.
45:42 Event: Kick-off by Monaco
45:50 Event: Foul by Arsenal

47:40 Event: Shots on target by Monaco
47:40 Event: Direct free-kick by Monaco

48:05 Event: Ball out of play

49:47 Caption: Nothing more will happen in this game as the referee blows for full time.
49:59 Caption: The fans must be pleased with the show they have seen on the pitch today. There was no chance to get bored as the game was very attractive. Let's hope the players won't lose their passion and determination in the future matches. There wasn't any evident superiority by either side today. The home side attempted to create scoring opportunities mostly with long balls, while the opposition focused on counter-attacks to breach the home side's defences.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
The matchup between Arsenal and Monaco was an enthralling encounter that kept fans on the edge of their seats throughout both halves, filled with dramatic turns and strategic plays. Arsenal kicked off the match sharply at 00:38, asserting their intent by immediately taking the initiative. The game, however, quickly fell into a rhythm of back-and-forth possession with the ball going out of play multiple times in the first few minutes, leading to several throw-ins primarily by Arsenal. 

Early efforts to get on the scoreboard manifested at 02:04 when Arsenal fired a shot that went off target, a precursor to their relentless pressure. Monaco, unfazed, responded with strong defensive actions, notably a clearance at 02:39. This became the game's initial dynamic, with Arsenal pushing up the field and Monaco repelling the attacks effectively.

Arsenal won a corner at 05:54, which became their first real set-piece opportunity. Yet, despite converting some corners, they weren't able to convert these into scoring chances owing primarily to Monaco's sturdy defensive unit, which consistently managed to clear the ball from danger zones. By 07:46, Monaco's discipline on the offside line showed as they forced an offside, granting Arsenal an indirect free-kick.

The physical nature of the game was underscored with regular fouls, commencing early when Aymen Abdennour of Monaco made a rough challenge at 12:07. Both teams began to show signs of aggressive play, with Deniz Aytekin blowing his whistle frequently.

Monaco spearheaded their counter-attacks smartly. Their strategy was to absorb pressure and look for opportunities to break quickly. Elderson teased a dangerous cross by Monaco at 13:18, which Arsenal handled without much fuss. On the other side, an over-eager Olivier Giroud committed an overly aggressive challenge by 14:07, signaling Arsenal's hunger but also hinting at desperation.

Dimitar Berbatov's penchant for hanging off defenders' shoulders frequently led him to be caught offside, evidenced multiple times around the 16-minute mark. Arsenal dominated possession through intricate passing, weaving through Monaco's defenders often but lacking the clinical finish to convert this into goals.

Notably, in the 20th minute, Berbatov received a smart cross from Almamy Toure but could not break the deadlock as Arsenal’s defense intervened bravely. A few minutes later, Arsenal orchestrated another attack that led to a corner at 22:15. Mesut Ozil delivered the ball into the danger area frequently, but Monaco's defense remained resolute.

Despite heavy pressing from Arsenal, notably Alexis Sanchez who came close on several occasions, Monaco was the first to break the deadlock. At the 37:12 mark, Geoffrey Kondogbia seized an opportunity to shoot from distance. The ball, significantly deflected, deceived David Ospina in goal and Monaco surged to a 1-0 lead. Arsenal restarted with even more urgency and piled on the pressure, but Giroud wasted a crucial header, sending it over the bar in the 40th minute. 

Arsenal's aggression grew as the half neared its end, causing mistimed tackles and leading to yellow cards for Francis Coquelin in the 41st minute and Elderson in the 45th. An effort from Giroud in the final minutes prompted Ozil to cross into the penalty area, only for it to be gathered safely by the alert Danijel Subasic, marking the end of the half with Monaco holding a one-goal advantage.

The second half began with Monaco kicking off and the audience sensing more drama. Arsenal created an early chance within the first minute as Giroud, after a brilliant pass from Sanchez, missed narrowly. This set a frenetic pace, reminiscent of the first half. Per Mertesacker of Arsenal fouled an opponent barely after it began, maintaining the heated match atmosphere.

Monaco's defensive solidity and quick reliance on counterattacks were evident once again. Despite sustained Arsenal pressure and a few calls for free-kicks, it was Monaco who extended their lead. At 47:40, Berbatov was released by Anthony Martial's swift pass, and he finished coolly to put Monaco 2-0 up.

Arsenal urgently searched for a response. Between defensive clearances and missed chances, including a notable miss by Alexis Sanchez who saw his shot saved stunningly by Subasic, their efforts were largely thwarted by Monaco's organized defense.

Arsenal made tactical changes, hoping to inject pace and fresh legs into their attack. Olivier Giroud made way for Theo Walcott at 14:35, and Francis Coquelin was substituted for Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain later on. Despite these shifts, Monaco was not just sitting back but also created chances, proving dangerous with glancing headers and shots from the edge of the box causing Arsenal to remain defensive.

It was a case of opportunities missed for Arsenal. Theo Walcott, at 18:50, managed a shot on target from close range only to experience the frustration of seeing it saved. Sanchez continued to be the creative force behind numerous efforts which, again, were met by Monaco's responsive rearguard, keeping them at bay repeatedly.

When Yannick Carrasco replaced Berbatov at the 30:06 mark, Monaco sought to balance their defensive efforts with an attempt to exploit any remaining lapses in Arsenal's defense. Arsenal fans saw more substitutions with Tomas Rosicky coming on for Santi Cazorla, signaling a last-ditch effort to rewrite the game’s fate.

Arsenal finally managed to break their duck at 45:06, when a fortuitous rebound landed at the feet of Oxlade-Chamberlain just outside the box. The midfielder struck cleanly, sending a powerful shot beyond the reach of Subasic and offering his team a glimmer of hope with the scoreline now 2-1.

However, this joy was short-lived. Monaco promptly reacted and less than a minute later, Yannick Carrasco, in a dazzling display of individual skill, netted the third goal for Monaco at 48:23. His superb effort culminated in a fine strike that found the net, leaving Arsenal’s defense lamenting yet again. And with that, the score stood at 3-1, effectively sealing Monaco's triumph. 

The referee’s whistle at the end of the match marked a night of missed opportunities for Arsenal. Despite their relentless pressing, the combination of Monaco's rapid counter-attacks and solid defending resulted in a 3-1 victory for the visitors. The home side's attempts to score through long balls and crosses did not deliver the desired results, whereas Monaco's efficient and precise counter-attacks proved to be lethal. Arsenal couldn't capitalize on set-pieces effectively and often saw their offensive forays subdued by a resilient Monaco defense. 

This match left both teams aware of their strengths and weaknesses, with Monaco capitalizing on Arsenal's lapses and the Gunners realizing the work needed to be done both in defense and finishing. As the fans dispersed, they took with them the memory of an electrifying encounter that underlined the unpredictable and thrilling nature of football.
